description.text:
This is designed for when your toilet paper holder doesn't have enough room for the larger toilet paper rolls. In our place the TP drags against the wall when we pull out the paper. This will friction fit over the ends of the already existing spindle that came with ours.
I don't know if there are proper names for the parts of the toilet paper holder, but these are the names that I'm going with. The tube that goes through the toilet paper, I'm calling the spindle. The part that sinks into the wall, is just the toilet paper holder, that's where the spindle connects to directly normally. The extender is the part that fits in between these two, and allows the toilet paper roll to come away from the wall a little. I have also included the beginnings of a replacement spindle, so I can replace the other one in our place I have printed the Toilet_paperholder-_endsextender.stl, and it works great. The only modification I'll have to do is file the nubs down a little, as they are a little snug in the main holder.

• Print toilet paper holder - extender.stl
    If your toilet paper holder is like mine, it should just quite snugly. I'll probably glue mine on when I'm happy with it.
  • Please let me know if you have any feed back on this.
    • Thanks,
    Stephen

title: Hair dryer nozzle adapter for air mattress

description.text: I have this blow up mattress that needs to be inflated every so often when I have guests over... thing is, I don't have a very good air pump to accompany it. But, I DO have a nice hair dryer with a 'cold' setting (H&D model number HD-1205). Its nozzle opening is 25mmx50mm whereas the blow up mattress opening is round... SO, I made this adapter. Works beautifully and I can skimp out on buying a real air pump. Yay! Now, that's what I call living the 3D print lifestyle.... aww-yeah! February 5th, 2016 update - added a version 2 with a special little pimple that allows it to snap on to the end of the hair dryer (instead of resorting to ghetto-ing it up with tape like I did in the pictures above). Does this bring us one step closer to world peace? Yes. Yes it does. I design stuff like this all the time, so feel free to peruse my other publications - who knows what you'll find you can't live without: http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

author: mfann72

description.text: Inspired by the "Keyboard Key Puller/Remover" by TBRIshtar, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:463824 Friend needed one, so I decided to print one for him. It works well but took quite a bit of force to depress into the keycaps (similar to the one that came with my Ducky keyboard). Turns out the prongs are too wide apart and thick. My version has thinner prongs and are narrower apart. The tips have been made stubbier but lower in height. This gives more clearance around keycaps, especially the Esc button. The net result is the keycap puller slips into the keycap with reduced force . Also added fillet to the prongs to relief stress concentration (for the heck of it). Finger hole is circle because FreeCAD doesn't support elipses. Attached FreeCAD file.

New Matter MOD-t

Notes: My experience with the New Matter MOD-t led me to recommend raft with all thin profile prints. This was no exception as many prints failed due to bed adhesion with this printer. YMMV.
Customized Raspberry Pi 2 Enclosure. Just a model, the top still needs to be made into a separate part with mounting holes.

The Bombardier Dash 8 or Q-Series, is a series of twin-engine turboprop airliners. Introduced by de Havilland Canada in 1984, they are now produced by Bombardier Aerospace. This model is the first to feature the all-in-one print file in it's original release. My remaining models will have all-in-ones added over time.
UPDATE: By popular request, I have also included the smaller Q200 model number for download. The model is not an "exact" replica of the Q200 (I was unable to find any schematic or dimensions to reference during the rebuild), it's pretty darned close. Enjoy!
Any trouble with the print? Let me know!
Version 1.0.7

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm Standard

Infill:

10% 0.4mm Diamond (fast)

Notes: I have been using four shells for redundancy, as the printers I've been working with occasionally drop off a shell for certain portions of the model. While I believe this to be the effect of the slicer (the locations of the missing shells are unpredictable and do not follow the pattern of a fault in the model itself), I have yet to determine the actual reasoning.

Design Process This model was produced in about 3hrs of work, split over two working days. The biggest improvement in overall design is the wing root. Previously the roots for my models have been a sphere, warped and shaped to roughly match the outline based on available dimensions. This model is the first to have the wing root designed to actually match the shape of the real-world aircraft, as best as possible.

This education project involves students creating tessellation patterns and printing those out as puzzle pieces. Developing math thinking involves looking for patterns. This activity is designed to encourage students to see patterns in the world around them. 3D printing is useful here because students understand concepts by manipulating physical objects through kinesthetic learning. The sample files provided here is an example of the kind of puzzles students could create. These puzzles could be shared with other students to further reinforce the concepts of tessellating patterns. Here is another example I created:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1470332 It also creates a nice piece of math art.

kendel3d created an awesome puzzle frame for this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2125154

If you want a better fit on this print, sand or file the edges of the fist layer after the print is done (that first layer tends to squish out a bit).

Design Process I started out by creating a cool design in a program called Tesselmaniac. The tessellating shape was exported as SVG file from Tesselmaniac and brought into a 3D modelling application and extruded. This same process could be used by students to engage in a compelling activity of exploring and recognizing patterns in the world around them. Note: I have contacted the author of Tesselmaniac and the program now has a features to export the outline of the tessellation shape in SVG format which is a 3D Model friendly format.
NGSS

Students will create tessellated shapes as part of math activity in order to explore patterns. They will then use a 3D modelling application to trace the object and extrude the shape into 3D space to create puzzles pieces allowing student to share their puzzles with their peers as a challenge game.

Objectives/Outcomes:
  • Students will learn to identify repeating patterns by creating and printing tessellating shapes.
  • Grade 6 math Curriculum (Alberta) PATTERNS AND RELATIONS Patterns: Use patterns to describe the world and to solve problems. 3-D Objects and 2-D Shapes: Describe the characteristics of 3-D objects and 2-D shapes,
    SHAPE AND SPACE (Transformations)
    General Outcome
    Describe and analyze position and motion of objects and shapes.
    Specific Outcomes
    1. Perform a combination of translations, rotations and/or reflections on a single 2-D shape, with and without technology, and draw and describe the image. [C, CN, PS, T, V]
    2. Perform a combination of successive transformations of 2-D shapes to create a design, and identify and describe the transformations. [C, CN, T, V]
    • Audiences:
  • Upper elementary students - a grade 3 tester really enjoyed working with the sample puzzle
    • Skills Learned
  • identification of shapes and patterns
  • designing games for other students
  • problem solving
  • seeing math in the world
  • create a tessellated 3D puzzle that can be physically put together
  • it will be shared with other students as a challenging puzzle
    • Lesson/Activity
  • Students begin by creating a tessellating shape pattern either with the computer program (Tesselmaniac) or by hand.
  • Once an interesting shape has been created, the teacher approves the design,
  • The student then traces out the shape in a 2D or 3D program - many applications allow you to import a picture and then trace it with the bezier curve tools or one might use a program like Adobe Illustrator or Inscape (free) and export in an appropriate format (e.g. svg). If you use Tesselmaniac, that program allows you to export the outline of the tessellating shape as a SVG file which is compatible with many 3D modeling applications. One way to do this is to import the file into a program like Inkscape delete all the other elements except for the polygon shape. Then export as an Inkscape SVG file. You can then import this into most 3D applications (e.g. 123D Design). In the case of 123D Design import "SVG as Solid". This will automatically extrude the shape.
  • Once the shape is created the students will extrude the shape to a desirable height.
  • After the shape is created, it is approved by the teacher and then multiple shapes are printed (the number is a function of the design). One can elect to print in different colours as well.
  • The resulting puzzles are shared and played amongst peers who are challenged by putting the pieces together into tessellating shapes.
    • Duration:
    This activity could be modified to take one lesson (e.g. for a class designed approach where the class designs and prints out the results) or it could be multiple lessons where individuals or groups design tessellation designs and then print those out. Depending on access to the 3D printers and time available the instructor can adjust the length of this activity. Preparation:
  • either purchase a copy of Tesslemaniac or use paper to create a tessellating shape. If using paper, multiple copies can be cut out to test the shape.
    • Resources:
  • http://www.tesselmaniac.com/tess/Home.html
  • http://www.learnalberta.ca/content/me5l/html/math5.html?goLesson=19
  • http://www.learnalberta.ca/content/mejhm/index.html?l=0&ID1=AB.MATH.JR.SHAP&ID2=AB.MATH.JR.SHAP.TRAN&lesson=html/object_interactives/transformations/use_it.html
  • https://www.universalclass.com/articles/math/geometry/what-are-tessellations.htm
  • https://www.exploratorium.edu/geometryplayground/Activities/GP_Activities_3-5/ExploringTessellations_3-5_v4.pdf

This is a model illustrating the conversion of continuous rotary motion into reciprocating indexing motion.
It's a fairly complex model with 22 different parts and quite a few M3 x 10mm long button head cap screws. I used about 34. You could get away with fewer - or use even more, about another 6.
The model was inspired by a simulation example in SimLab Composer Mechanical v6.18
It was designed in Moi (Moment of Inspiration) simulated in SimLab Composer Mechanical and printed on an Ultimaker original (modified) in Diamond Age PLA
A video of the completed model is available here:https://youtu.be/rsHtbFcT21w
And a simulation of the concept here: https://youtu.be/dwXFKS28kUQ

Generally when I design a shaft and hole I give both the same nominal size, eg 8mm. (Actually I make the hole (if it is a clearance hole) a tiny bit larger otherwise simulation doesn't work),.
Then to make a nice sliding fit I size the hole with a hand reamer.
If the hole is not reamed out then the shaft is a tap fit into the hole.
NOTE that the handle stem is a tap fit into the handle lever so do NOT ream out the hole in the handle lever.
NOTE as I don't yet have a 14mm reamer I added 'geneva base no reamer' file which has a larger bore.
If you are using hand reamers then these handles may be of interest: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:386855
I also clean out the entry of holes that will be self tapped by the 3mm screws, with a tapered reamer. I have one of these: http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/Tapered-Reamer-Driver-tool-0-to-14mm-Expanding-Hole-Opener-RC-Helicopter-DIY-/121804439198?hash=item1c5c1c3e9e:g:t98AAOSwAYtWLdXy
Spend some time making sure that sliding parts do so easily. Especially the rack in its supports. I found it necessary to clean the print table side of the rack teeth and the gear teeth.
I recommend assembly with the rack central and the gear and geneva arranged as show in the first photo. Not that the last part to be fastened in place should be the 'block arm and roller'.
Just rememebered - take care when assembling the geneva to its base as the holes are not evenly arranged.

description.text:
MonTagger Named for the protagonist of Fahrenheit 451 and French for "my tagger," MonTagger along with an OpenFrameworks Application provide a means for tracking a pen or can through CV(computer vision). To solve the problem of occlusion to the camera, the device emits 2 laser lines which intersect at the point of contact for a pen or spray can. This means that the camera simply needs to see 2 line segments to then compute where they intersect, resulting in where the pen or can is actively being used. The device only requires:
  • 2x lasers (red, green, IR...)
  • 3x AAA batteries (anything that can provide ~2.7-3.5v)
  • a push button (switch)
  • 3D printed case to attach the above to writing instrument
    (Note: I would love to see a hack for laser cut parts instead, it is so much faster and accessible to recreate)

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Form 1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Resolution:

0.05mm

Notes: Printed on the Form 2 printer with wonderful results. Note: Try and keep the supports off of the threads.
Analyzing the cross section of the form in Fusion360 A rendering of the soon to be finished product

MonTagger Software MonTagger relies on some OpenCV detection to calculate where the drawing is occurring. More information will be posted soon about this on Github, here: https://github.com/jbobrow/MonTagger

comments.text: After you have the tag recorded, what do you do with it? Is this something that can then be transformed into a 3d rendering and then 3d printed?
comments.author: istilesm

comments.text: Great question. Some good examples of what can be done with it can be found at http://www.graffitimarkuplanguage.com. The idea is that the OpenFrameworks app that interprets the pen position records all of the data in GML, then can be used for all sorts of creative purposes. Coming from the same minds, http://graffitianalysis.com/ is a tool for capturing GML as well as playing it back with some slick effects. And lastly, here:http://www.evan-roth.com/work/graffiti-analysis-cap-2012/ is a beautiful example of a 3D print using the XY data and then mapping time to the Z coordinate. I believe velocity is used for line/pipe thickness.
comments.author: istilesm

comments.text:
Yeah I used to have the graffiti analysis app and loved messing around with it. I'm also familiar with that project by Evan Roth and love how it came out. I've always wanted to do that and now I have most of the tools to do it.
I would love to do that with some of my own drawings. Do you have experience with the whole process?(From recording a tag all the way to having a 3d print of it?)
comments.author: jbobrow

comments.text: This is my first foray into GML, so haven't been through the whole experience yet. Surely there will be plenty to learn in the process. I am also looking for help with the CV tracking of the lines, the current app is posted here: https://github.com/jbobrow/MonTagger (more documentation coming as well)

Turn your Dremel into a blower or vacuum. It works really well! .75" ID output port, 2.15" inlet. Inlet bolt circle is 2.438" in diameter, and is for 6 4-40 bolts. Printed on a Fablicator!
www.fablicator.com EDIT: The Impeller I believe is backwards. It still works very well, though. I'm going to re-print a mirrored version to see if it makes any difference. EDIT2: The impeller works about the same despite being right or left handed. go figure.

Disclamer!!!
Wear Safety glasses when first turning this on! The impeller tips spin at 200mph and will not hesitate to injure you if the impeller comes apart! Make sure the print is very good quality before spinning it up! Use at your own risk!
Print all 3 pieces. 
Screw the neck onto the Dremel until snug. 
Thread the Impeller onto the Dremel shaft. It might be a little tight, but will go on with a little effort. It must be threaded on completely, so there is ~1/16" clearance between the bottom of the impeller and the neck. Be careful not to break the blades, though!
Attach the shroud. The alignment pins should all line up and snap together with the alignment holes. Screw the neck and shroud together with (6) 4-40 X .25" screws.
Congratulations, your Dremel is now even more multi-purpose!

This is a modified version of the MakeItLoud V29 Whistle that puts out 118+db. I made the design a lot thinner and a little smaller so it can be more portable.
I also added a second hole that works very well on a smaller keychain. The original design didn't sound very well if you did not blow very hard, but this one works pretty well even if you blow more slowly and less loud, but it still gets REALLY loud if you blow hard. I really liked the original whistle, but this saves me time, plastic, and space!

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select (Prusa i3)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

I used MeshMixer by Autodesk to Modify the original STL file. I didn't know this at the time, but it generated a ridiculously large file. It has A LOT of polygons. I went back to try to remove as many as I could, but the Reduce function didn't really do much, so I manually remeshed the areas and was able to reduce the size an extra 30%. Tips to fix it are welcome in the comments! UPDATE Thanks to the remix by curious_pl I found out about Blender, so I used it to bring down the mesh even further to around 600kB.
Sorry for the big file troubles, I'm still learning! Also, at the request of jzisa, I made a video comparing the loudness of the original V29 vs this version with a crude iPhone decibel meter

I was feeling cheep and did not want to buy a switch so i designed and printed one. Now i can make as many as i need. Also no solder required just wire and a 3d printer..

Print all parts. Cut some small wire 12 inches and coil it around the inner switch. After that loop the some wire around the holes in the outer switch . place the inner switch in the outer switch. test then close with the switch cover and melt the two tabs to hold it together.

This is bowden type extruder. It is designed to be in a small formfactor, support hard Filaments like old PLA, but also print flexible materials like Ninjaflex. It uses 1.75mm filament. With the opener you can release the stress from the filament to change it quickly.
The Parts are designed to be printed without Supports.
It can be mounted on the outside of your printer with the adapter. The adapter mounting holes are compatible with the Airtripper Bowden Extruder.
Also you could mount it in your Case like in the 3Dator. The stepper motor goes inside and the extruder outside. The material between should be 4-5mm. See how it is put together here:
http://wiki.3dator.com/index.php/Bauanleitung/en#Extruder See the Printer in action printing Ninjaflex here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mxCev5Obq2g If you don't like to get all parts yourself you can buy the extruder here:
https://3dator.com/en/shop/3dator-extruder/ Updates:
24.04.2016:
  • Optimised filament channel for better flow.
    • 09.08.2016:
  • Again optimised filament channel (works best with mk7 gear for 1.75mm filament)
  • added a file with the complete extruder ready to print
  • added a hook with a hole to see what your mk7 gear is doing and check if it is aligned (Thanks to 50koruny for the idea)
  • added a mirrored version for dual extruders to our github repo: https://github.com/3Dator/3dator/tree/master/stl/extra/extruder_mirrored
    • 23.03.2017:
  • updated the tightener to use M3 self-locking nuts (we noticed the squere nuts are too loose and won't always remain in the desired position) You can find the old file still on github: https://github.com/3Dator/3dator/blob/1e32c3fe1a329b2f864e2268b2501e233c2439be/stl/extruder/tightener.stl
    • 22.08.2017:
    updated the adapter.stl to be a bit more usable. Now there is also a step file in our git repository. You can find the complete file history in our github repository:
    https://github.com/3Dator/3dator/tree/master/stl/extruder
    Here you find the Step files:
    https://github.com/3Dator/3dator/tree/master/step/extruder You Need:
    Push fittings 4mm M5:
    http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/NRrby76 Mk7 Extruder Gear:
    http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/bAAm6un MR105ZZ Bearing
    http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/amIayfE 608ZZ Bearing
    http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/fAI6UnQ

Printer:

3Dator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: We always print this with 3 perimeters to make it stronger.
To get better results with the M3 holes in extruder_base we closed them with 2 layers. Just open them again with a drill.

Beside the pla for printing the parts you will need the following parts:
1x MR105ZZ
1x 608ZZ
1x MK7 gear for 1.75mm filament
2x M3 self locking nuts
2x M3 40mm screws
3x M3 25mm screws
1x PTFE fitting PC4-M5 (M5 screw, for 4mm ptfe tube)
1x Nema 17 Stepper Motor

If you want to use a MK8 drive gear instead of a mk7 check out the remix of 50koruny:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1679553
He also added a "window" to have a look inside to see what's going on.

Finding the right tension This Extruder is supporting a wide spectrum of different filaments.
Usually you only need to tighten one screw, which makes it more easy to find the right tension. For Filaments, that need to get squeezed quite hard, like old PLA or Ninjaflex you should tighten up both screws.
For printing Ninjaflex, you may print the Extruder Base with a nozzle as fine as possible and with a 0,1 mm layer height.

comments.text: This is one awesome extruder setup. I have looked at many different Bowden type extruder mounts and this one by far is the most universal. The fact that this will now be away from the hotend is a HUGE advantaged in several ways. Less weight, thus less mass to move and less artifacts, also stepper will run cooler as the heatbreak is no where neat the extruder.

title: Universal Phone Tripod Mount with integrated thread

description.text:
Been meaning to post this for a while. I adapted the phone mount for a friend as we were having difficulty sourcing the thread insert for the tripod so I adapted the model to include a thread in the print.  
I've also flattened the models to the build plate.

Just print off all the separate items and then I found running a tap into the hole and inserting M3 (from memory) to hold things together works just fine. Find a suitable spring or use a rubber band to hold the phone in place if you so desire.

title: Hammerhead Ribozyme
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hammerhead Ribozyme. "The hammerhead ribozyme is a RNA molecule motif that catalyzes reversible cleavage and joining reactions at a specific site within an RNA molecule. It serves as a model system for research on the structure and properties of RNA, and is used for targeted RNA cleavage experiments, some with proposed therapeutic applications."
--https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hammerhead_ribozyme This model is of the Hammerhead ribozyme (1hmh-A_fixed.stl; blue in the figures) in complex with a DNA substrate analogue (1hmh-B_fixed.stl; red in the figures) Model of based on the Protein Data Bank entry 1HMH:
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=1hmh STL file created using VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

standard

Notes: Successfully printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator2 using MakerBot Desktop 3.9.0.961, standard resolution with 3 shells and 25% infill. Use rafts and supports.

comments.text:
As a fellow scientist i am sure you can appreciate the question what "standard" resolution is.
Personally i use 100um Z-axis and 400um xy axis as my standard resolution. So i was wondering what your nozzle size and Z-height was to print this protein structure. (Other tips/pointers relevant to protein model printing i have not found yet are also helpful of course.)
comments.author: Reapingminer

comments.text: One of the differences between printers is resolution, so I don't think it's possible to talk about standard resolution. On my replicator 2 I use layer height 0.2 mm. XY resolution is not well defined on this printer. Ultimately, the limiting factor will be the mesh defined by the STL file.
comments.author: Reapingminer

title: Tunell Filament Monitor mounting arm for Fusion3 F306 printer. (Experimental)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a preliminary mounting arm for using a Tunell Filament Monitor on a Fusion3 F306 printer. The Tunell Filament Monitor is designed to detect filament feeding problems caused by filament jams and from running out of filament. You can purchase the Tunell Filament Monitor at http://www.toybuilderlabs.com/products/tunell-3d-printer-filament-monitor

Installation Use M3x8 screws to mount the Tunell monitor to the arm. Snap the arm onto the right-front frame T-slot extrusion. Use a zip-tie to secure the arm. 3-wire connection to the MX1 connector for power, ground, and fault-detect signal.

description.text:
I designed this soap box to work well inside the shower and in a suitcase for travel. 
The box has a perforated bottom with a slight incline to drain the water that will fall in the box when taking the soap in and out during the shower. The soap rests on a removable honey-comb grid elevated above the bottom. This allows the water to drain more easily and for the soap to dry quicker after the shower. I made the grid removable for easy cleaning and to let you print a solid piece if you want to store the soap for a longer time or other things entirely. The lid slides and closes the box completely to protect the soap from erosion by the water in the shower. It also stays in place well enough to put in a suitcase for travel and avoid getting soap residue on your other things.
I have tested this box for the past 2 weeks and it has worked great! I hope you guys like it too.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select (Prusa i3)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Depending on your settings you might want to print at a higher infill to prevent water getting inside the walls of the box, but 20% was good enough for me.

This is my very first project in OpenSCAD. Tracks are designed from scratch, the goal was to shorten print time and to increase bottom surface - to avoid delamination of ABS from the hotbed.
One try was attempted to print the straight track, but was unsuccessful due to printer failure - new attempts will follow next week. Note: you need OpenSCAD 2016 to modify/render the curved track, 2015 has no angle parameter in rotate_extrude. 2016-03-09: All files were updated (actually, the old curved track was not printable) - I have printed several copies of both rails. They connected smootly to each other and to the original Duplo. 2016-03-18: Increased width: distance between rails from 27 to 28 mm, rail thickness from 1.5 to 2 mm because my dauther have broken one 1.5 mm rail, track width from 7 to 9 mm - because one wheel could drop down from the old version of the straight track. Sorry guys, I have not so much time for testing, and my children do not report bugs immediately :)

description.text:
A modified case for the IR eye. 1) Magnets are dropped in during printing .
2) A hole in the top for a plug.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20%

Notes: When the print is about 50% done. Pause the printer and drop the magnets in place. You can insert the gcode M71 in the gcode file to pause the print at the correct time. I have done this in the zip file included, which is for a Replicator 2X. Here are the steps:
  • Export your print from Maker Desktop as a gcode file.
  • Edit the gcode file
    • Search for the slice that begins after 8mm (Z8.200). If you print in 0.2mm per slice, it will be slice 40.
    • Before the slice begins inset this:
      ;Move printer to waiting position and pause
      G1 X-112 Y-73 Z150 F3300.0 (move to waiting position)
      M71
    • Save the file
  • Convert to x3g
    • Use the tool here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:81425
    • I used this command:
      gpx.exe -g -m r2x kamstrup-bottom.gcode

author: brickgenerate

description.text: The second version of Modular Y carriage. this time the carriage and screw holes are modeled based on the pcb dimension spec found from here http://reprap.org/wiki/PCB_Heatbed The corners are now symmetrical and there's only one type of corner to be printed multiple times. Also all of the models/objects are less than 130mm and can be printed by most 3d printer bed size. Most carriage designed by others requires big print and not to mention that some users don't prefer to print something big in one shot (I'm one of em) Multiple beam lengths are also included to cater other pcb sizes; 200 x 200, 300 x 200 and 300 x 300 The corners also features nut trap hole to enable you guys to adjust the bed with just single hand only without any additional add-on to trap the nut in place. The adapter screw holes are made to be used with the y belt holder found in BOM section down below. Do check out the V3 too over here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1345816

Only printers that are properly tuned for precision are able to use this y carriage. Because there cannot be any wobble/loose ends on the y carriage, everything must be snap fit or tight fit together to avoid any printout defects later. I would suggest to print one of the beam file and test it with m3 screw, it should have slight resistance when inserting into the hole but not up to the point until you have to use screw driver to force it through
Do note that the width of the linear rail/rod won't be the same as the previous one. to those who're using acrylic or any laser cut y rod mount might not able to fit with this one due to beam lengths

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes: Enable supports for "Diagonal 300 x 200.stl" because the diagonal beam cannot be printed sideways. There are no alternative than this. Just minor support only =) It is recommended to be printed using ABS material or any material that can withstand up to 120'c heat generated from the bed
Bill of Materials

• 4 x Corners
  • 4 x Diagonal S
  • 8 x Beam S
  • 1 x Adapter

• 4 x Corners
  • 4 x "Diagonal 300 x 200"
  • 4 x Beam S
  • 4 x Beam L
  • 1 x Adapter

• 4 x Corners
  • 4 x Diagonal L or 8 x Diagonal M
  • 8 x Beam L
  • 1 x Adapter

• 16 x M3 x12 screws (add extra 4 if you're using Diagonal M)
  • 8 x M3 x 12 or longer for beams (with this you can add any add-ons with the current mountings)
  • M3 nut to fix everything in place
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745934
    • Extra Notes If you're going to add some accessories or mount to this carriage, I suggest mount them through the beams in the center with 2 screws together. The distance for both is roughly about 8.875mm (hole center). The beam and diagonal with "geeetech" means it has the same dimension as geeetech's acrylic carriage dimension. I'm using geeetech by the way Update Plans
  • Designing the lm8uu to sit close together near the center to achieve more travel length
  • Simplify current design to cater simplicity yet rigid structure
  • Elevate Y carriage so it won't get blocked by any types of rod holder/mount
  • Add-on for V2

comments.text: I like it quite alot, but wish that there were different places to put the bearings. I'm limited to the linear rods that I currently have, so being able to have the bearings more central in the build would allow people to use a much larger build area. With the current implementation, you basically have to have linear rods that are just over double the length of your build plate if you're wanting to use up the entire build surface (as in, something like a 425/450mm rod in order to take advantage of the full build area of a 200mm print bed, since most print beds are actually around 205/210mm, and the space required to 'attach' the rods to the 'frame', also eat up valuable travel distance as well).

comments.text: I actually don't have a Prusa i3. I'm converting my current printer "into" a Prusa i3. My current printer is quite literally just a box made out of 2"x4" pieces of soft wood, screwed together with masonry screws lol. The only components of the printer that isn't cut/made by hand is the extruder, the hot end, the head bed, the bearings, belts, stepper motors, and the hardened rods. I spent maybe 50 dollars max on making this printer if you don't include the RAMPS board. The majority of parts I just happened to have lying around from when i disassembled countless printers and xerox machines lol. I took all the rods, stepper motors, bearings, and belts from them. Hence why I've called this POS printer "JankyBot" lol.

title: Printable T-Slot nut for Misumi Extrusions

description.text: Allows you to use a plain M4 nut in place of the more expensive T-Slot nuts. I don't recommend using these for the main structural components of a MendelMax until further testing is done, though they would probably be fine, but they will be perfect for adding accessories.

Print them out, clean up the hole if necessary, insert an M4 nut. FAQ:
Q: Why m4? Why not use M5? A: M5 will not fit in the slot. An M5 Jam nut might fit, but I have not been able to source them locally. Q: Can I use a 6-32 nuts? A: Probably. I have not tested 6-32 nuts, but they should fit, with some minor adjustments to the CAD file. I will pick up some 6-32 nuts and confirm.

title: Dual Monitor Stand/Arm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hope you like this monitor stand. Its intended for two Dell U2312HM on top of each other. Others may work as well since the stand uses the standard VESA Mount which is found on almost all flat screens. 
The angle of the monitors can be adjusted.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

screws: 100%, alll other parts: 50%

Notes: All parts included. :-) Edit: I recommend printing this in ABS. I tried it in PLA and it broke apart after several weeks. Maybe it also helps to increase the extruder temperature to improve the layer adhesion (I printed with 190°C which I suppose is relatively cold). Some parts need to be scaled since they are not exported to the correct size by my CAD Tool.
The scaling factor is 10. Before you print the Spacer, you should measure the exact space between the arms where the vesamount bolts to. Scale the spacer so it fits in snug. Not doing so might break the arms or the vesamount when you tighten the screws. The Assembly is just to show how everything is put together.

Weld the mainstand parts together using a Dremel and this technique:
http://hackaday.com/2014/12/30/3d-printing-technique-friction-welding/ Weld the Adjusternut to the appropriate position. Weld the Adjuster Pin to both Adjuster Bolts. Assemble everything. Done. :-)

comments.text: Since a 32" monitor will be very heavy I recommend using the lower position only. Then there is a chance it will work, but I can not promise.

title: Rhino (Tank) - Grand Theft Auto: Vice City

description.text:
This is the "tank" model (Rhino) from GTA3 or GTA Vice City (I extracted from GTA Vice City).
It is an arrangement to be able to spin the wheels and rotate the turret. Also, I fixed the empty polygons to avoid print issues.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes: I reduce the print speed to 50% to the first layers.
Then change it to 70-80%.

I took the GTA3 Tool to open the GTA files. I searched inside and I found the rhino.dff and I exported it.
I opened with the 3Ds Max and I fixed all the empty Polygons. Then, I divided the turret and I created an axis and a hole on the chassis. I did the same for the wheels. I created 6 holes for the wheels and then a wheel with an axis.

title: CONCEPT OF A DESIGN OF A POWER PLANT PRODUCTION USING SEA WAVES

description.text:
Aware of the need for electricity in the world, I decided to make my contribution, atravÃ©z the suggestion of a project using the motion of ocean waves.
Trough of research on the subject, I discovered that there is sophisticated technologies that are already in operation, producing energy through the movement of the waves, and even sea currents.
I did the design concepts using simple system of a water wheel, which among other uses is also used to produce electricity.
Naturally, the motion is very different from sea waves with the stream of a river, which is stable only in one direction, while at sea, the water moves in two directions, beyond which there is considerable unevenness in the level of sea ââas a consequence of the movement of the waves.
For it to be possible to apply this principle of force of water moving propeller that produce energy in ocean waves, had to make some adadaptaÃ§Ãµes as a floating base, and on it the entire installation of the propeller directly connected to the generator.
This floating base finds itself supported by four pillars, firmly rooted in the seabed. These four pillars protrude beyond the water level, and in them the floating base moves freely up and down as the wave motion of the sea.
To drive the propeller, which is about five feet long and two feet in diameter, which is connected to two generators at both ends, the sea water enters a channel of eighty centimentros high. The entrance of this channel has a funnel-shaped opening of 45 degrees. This is where the water is funneled into the channel where the propeller.
The propeller finds itself supported slightly above the center of the channel, so that the water reaches the middle thereof, and rotates thereby.
The housing which surrounds the entire system with a rounded shape in an elliptical shape to facilitate the flow of water passing underneath, and thereby elevating the whole also completely seals the interior so that water passes through the channel where only finds the propeller installed in the middle of the set. This sealing occurs against the opening 45 degrees with the housing, on both sides, because both the front and back of the casing opening is the same.
In this opening, there is formed a grid protection atravÃ©z openings in the housing of the assembly itself to prevent elements pass through this opening, such as fish of a certain size, or debris, which could halt the propeller.
Access to the interior of the system is by a door located on the side of the housing, which should naturally be at a safe distance from the sea level. For interior lighting, you can install skylights in the ceiling.
The system works by both the water inlet of the waves passing through the channel by the propeller as well as the output side, since the return flow of the water from this water and this passes in the opposite direction and accordingly drives the propeller . For that reason they, the generator should work for rotation in both directions, clockwise and counterclockwise.
To complete, on top of the pillars, there is a set of beams that bind, and also support a mast that has luminaire that aims to illuminate around at night, and also a flag to identify its presence in the sea at night.
In the case of exposure to an idea, demonstrated and made freely atravÃ©z drawings, any kind of calculation has been done, since I do not have this qualification.
Would be interesting if this project were analyzed by technicians to see the feasibility of producing electricity by this system.
The text has been automatically translated from Portuguese into English, atravÃ©z the Google Translator. It may be that some words slipped out of context.
If there is anyone who wants to contact me to comment on the project, my email is [email protected]

In terms of a concept of a project done on an idea, what you can do is print on 3d a prototype miniature.
Disponibilizei a file with all the external part, for the purpose of viewing.
The complete parts of the whole are in 3DS format, in a file, and also finds available for download.

description.text: Prusa i3 Z-axis rod holder Use a 22mm bearing (8mm inside, 7mm height). Fit it in the designed hole. Stick the Z-axis rod in it. Stick the other rod in the other hole. Attach to the stock top cap and there's no more shaking.

comments.text: This is not a good idea. The holes where the z axis threaded rods go through are over sized for a reason. A rod that is not perfectly straight, as many are not, needs to be free to wobble otherwise the bearing on the smooth rod will bind as the threaded rod will apply undesirable force to the bearing. A bit of threaded rod wobble does not matter as it is the smooth rods and bearings that stabilise the Z axis.
comments.author: Geoffs

title: Turnigy Fabrikator Bed height adjustment knob

description.text:
Turnigy Fabrikator Bed height adjustment knob This is a replacement knob for the bed Z height adjustment knob on the back of the printer.
I found that the original knob had some play in it and a larger tighter one allowed finer control over setting the minimum Z height. It is a replacement to the one pictured. I’ve printed it in PLA and prints fine and fits well. You might need to drill centre whole out a little to allow bolt to easily fit. To fit to your printer, unbolt the existing knob using a 7mm socket. Pull the existing knob from the back of the printer and insert the new version knob. Reconnect knob using existing bolt and nut. Tighten to snug and recalibrate you bed using Autohome as per the manual.

title: Customizable ipad, iphone, tablet stand / holder / dock

description.text:
Holder/stand/dock for ipad, iphone, other tablets & smart phones, which allow viewing tablet / phone screen hand-free. You can download and print directly. Or you can click on "Open in Customizer" to customize the model to your taste, before printing. You can change base width (for example, if you want wider based holder, and having more colored stripes), base length, device thickness (for example, to suit your thicker tablet), device inclination, dock thickness and, especially, you can also change the style by parameters X and Y. The length unit is millimeter, the angle unit is degree. The default model was tested with iPhone 6 / iPhone 6s, iPhone 5 / iPhone 5s, iPad Air, iPad Air 2, Samsung Tab S, Sony Xperia, in landscape and portrait modes. The customized "strawberry", "orange" and "kiwi" are also tested with iPhone 6, iPad Air 2 and Samsung Tab S. Printing time for default model with one colour should be less than 10 minutes. To make multiple colored stripes, I paused the printing at the right layer, changed the filament with different color, then continued, then repeated again for other color(s). For example, if printing with 0.3mm layer thickness for default model, there would be 54 layers to be printed; I changed the filaments at the end of layer 18 and layer 36 to make three colored stripes. Update: After the comments of users, I added:
  • Optional ring for keychain
  • Customizable thickness at the depression for hooking phone/tablet
  • Customizable (optional) text on the bottom of the stand.

Printer:

Unknown

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Printing time for default model with one colour should be about 7 minutes. To make multiple colored stripes, I paused the printing at the right layer, changed the filament with different color, then continued, then repeated again for other color(s). For example, if printing with 0.3mm layer thickness for default model, there would be 54 layers to be printed; I changed the filaments at the end of layer 18 and layer 36 to make three colored stripes.

Customization You can now click on "Open in Customizer" to customize the model to your taste. You can change base width, for example, if you want wider based holder, and having more colored stripes. You can change base length, especially to support big devices or portrait mode. You can change device thickness, for example, to suit your thicker tablet. You can change device inclination. Note that increasing inclination of device should be accompanying with increasing base length, so that the device will not tip over. You can change dock thickness. Thicker dock is stronger. And finally, you can also change style and, to certain extend, the rigidity of the dock, by adjusting Backing X and Backing Y. Try, for example, X=0 and Y=0 ("orange" style), or X=0 and Y=26 ("kiwi" style), or X=9 and Y=12 ("strawberry" style) to see some of the possibilities. Details on those styles are on the "Remixes" tab. Try other combinations for yourself :) The length unit is millimeter, the angle unit is degree.

comments.text:
Hello! I really like the simplicity of your design. I think it will be very useful when I print it. This is something I'm not very comfortable with: as you can see in the image (this is ipad.stl), the zone you put the phone only has 2 walls. I'm afraid I'm going the break the model when trying to pry it off the build plate and I also would feel a little more secure if there was at least two more walls in that part. This would also give it more resistance I think.
Do you think you can modify that?
Thank you!
comments.author: alc112

comments.text: Hi alc112, this design is customizable. Click on the "Open in Customizer" link on the right (under the "Thing Apps Enabled") , then increase the "Dd Thickness at depression (millimeter)" to your preferred value. When finish, press "Create Thing" to generate your new customized thing. Good luck!
